### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 82 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookie—oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar. Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday) and each batch is made, from start to finish, on a single day. The following conditions apply: No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day. At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday. The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies. The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
Question: If the number of batches made on Friday is exactly one, then which one of the following could be true?
Choices:
  A: The first batch of sugar cookies is made on Monday.
  B: The first batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Tuesday.
  C: The third batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Friday.
  D: The first batch of peanut butter cookies is made on Wednesday.
  E: The second batch of peanut butter cookies is made on Tuesday.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  - Three types of cookies: oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  - Three batches of each type of cookie are made each week, from Monday to Friday.
  - Each batch of cookies is made on a single day and no two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  - If the number of batches made on Friday is exactly one, then it is clear that at least one of the types of cookies will not be made on Friday.
 
Analysis: 
  - From the given conditions, there are only two batches of sugar cookies, and the second batch is made on Thursday, so no batch of sugar cookies can be made on Friday.
  - Similarly, there are only two batches of oatmeal cookies, and the second batch is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies. This means that the first batch of peanut butter cookies and the second batch of oatmeal cookies will always be made on the same day. So if the second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Friday, that means the second batch of peanut butter cookies will also be made on Friday, but only one batch is made on Friday. That means the third batch of oatmeal cookies cannot be made on Friday.
  - Therefore we can eliminate options C and E.

Action: Answer("A")  
Explanation: 
  - If the first batch of sugar cookies is made on Monday, then two batches of sugar cookies can be made on the remaining days of the week. This allows for one batch of oatmeal and one batch of peanut butter cookies to be made each on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. This means that on Friday, only one batch of cookies will be made, which satisfies the given condition.
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  - The bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookies—oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar, with exactly three batches of each kind of cookie made each week (Monday through Friday).
  - No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  - At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  
Analysis:
  - If the number of batches made on Friday is exactly one:
    - Then there must be a total of 8 batches made from Monday through Friday. (3 batches of each type of cookie and one batch on Friday)
    - The first batch of sugar cookies is not made on Monday (from the given information)
    - The second batch of sugar cookies is not made on Friday (from the given information)
    - There can only be one batch made on Friday.
      - If the third oatmeal batch is made on Friday, then the first oatmeal batch must be made on Monday (to satisfy the condition that no other oatmeal batch is made on the same day).
        - Therefore the first peanut batch would have to be made on Tuesday, and the second peanut batch would have to be made on Wednesday.
        - However, this violates the condition that no two batches of the same kind of cookie can be made on the same day.
      - If the first oatmeal batch is made on Tuesday, then the first peanut batch must be on Monday (to satisfy the condition that no other peanut batch is made on the same day).
        - Therefore the second peanut batch would be made on Thursday, and the second oatmeal and sugar batches are made on Wednesday.
        - This satisfies all the given conditions.
          
Action: Answer("B")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  A bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookie—oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  Three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday) and each batch is made, from start to finish, on a single day.
  No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies. 
  The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.

Analysis:
  If only one batch is made on Friday, two batches must be made on some other day and three batches must be made on another day.
  At least one of the batches made on Monday is not an oatmeal or a peanut butter cookie.
  The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies, so they must be made on different days, but the second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday and no two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day. So, second batches of oatmeal and peanut butter cookie can only be made on Tuesday or Wednesday.
  If the first batch of sugar cookies is made on Monday and the second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday, no more batches of sugar cookies can be made.
  If the first batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Tuesday and the first batch of peanut butter cookies is made on Wednesday, then the third batch of oatmeal cookies can be made on Friday.
 
Action: Answer("C")
Response 3:
Knowledge: 
  A bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookie—oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday) and each batch is made, from start to finish, on a single day.
  No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  
  If the number of batches made on Friday is exactly one, then there must be one batch of oatmeal cookies, one batch of peanut butter cookies, and one batch of sugar cookies that is scheduled for Friday.

A: The first batch of sugar cookies is made on Monday. - Not possible as no two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
B: The first batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Tuesday. - Not possible as the second batch of oatmeal cookies should be made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
C: The third batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Friday. - Not possible as there can only be one batch of oatmeal cookies made on Friday.
D: The first batch of peanut butter cookies is made on Wednesday. - Possible as the second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies, and there must be one batch of peanut butter cookies, one batch of oatmeal cookies, and one batch of sugar cookies that is scheduled for Friday. 
E: The second batch of peanut butter cookies is made on Tuesday. - Not possible as the second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 4:
Knowledge: 
  A bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookie—oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar. Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday) and each batch is made, from start to finish, on a single day. No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day. At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday. The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies. The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.

If the number of batches made on Friday is exactly one, there are two possible schedules that satisfy the conditions: 

Schedule 1: 
Mon: oatmeal 1, peanut butter 1, sugar 1
Tue: oatmeal 2, peanut butter 3, sugar 2
Wed: oatmeal 3, peanut butter 2, sugar 3
Thu: oatmeal 3, peanut butter 3, sugar 1
Fri: oatmeal 2, peanut butter 2, sugar 2

Schedule 2: 
Mon: oatmeal 1, peanut butter 1, sugar 1
Tue: oatmeal 2, peanut butter 2, sugar 2
Wed: oatmeal 3, peanut butter 3, sugar 3
Thu: oatmeal 3, peanut butter 2, sugar 1
Fri: oatmeal 2, peanut butter 3, sugar 2

Only schedule 2 satisfies Choices B, C, and E.

Choice A is not possible because the first batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday, not Monday. 
Choice D is not possible because the first peanut butter cookies are made on Monday or Thursday, not Wednesday.

Action: Answer("B, C, E")
Response 5:

  * Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday).
  * Each batch is made, start to finish, on a single day.
  * No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  * At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  * The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  * The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  
Action: Answer("B")  
Explanation: 
If the number of batches made on Friday is exactly one, then there are only two possibilities that allow each type of cookie to be made three times and follow the given conditions: the batches on Friday are PB, O, S (in that order), or the batches on Friday are PB, S, O (in that order). In either case, the first batch of oatmeal cookies must be made on Tuesday so that the second batch is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies. Thus, B is the only option that could be true.

  We know at least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.

Action: Answer("D") 
Explanation: 
  If only one batch of cookies is made on Friday, then the other 8 batches must have been baked on Monday through Thursday. Since there are no repeated batches on the same day and the second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday, the third batch of sugar cookies must have been baked on Friday. 
  It follows that the first and second batches of sugar cookies were baked on Monday and Tuesday, in some order. 
  There are only three batches remaining to be baked on Monday through Thursday: the first and third batches of oatmeal cookies and the first batch of peanut butter cookies. 
  Because the second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies, and no two batches of the same flavor can be made on the same day, the first batch of peanut butter cookies must have been made on Wednesday. 
  Therefore, the answer is D: The first batch of peanut butter cookies is made on Wednesday.

  - There are exactly three kinds of cookie: oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  - Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week.
  - No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  - At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  
Analysis:

    1. One batch of oatmeal cookies, one batch of peanut butter cookies, and one batch of sugar cookies were made on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday respectively. On Thursday, a batch of sugar cookies and a batch of oatmeal cookies were made. On Friday, only one batch of peanut butter cookies was made.

  - D: The first batch of peanut butter cookies cannot be made on Wednesday because oatmeal cookies are made on Monday and Wednesday.
  - E: The second batch of peanut butter cookies could be made on Tuesday since there are oatmeal cookies and sugar cookies made on this day and this option does not violate any of the conditions.

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 84 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Exactly five movies are showing at the repertory theater this evening: a horror film, a mystery, a romance, a sci-fi film, and a western. Each movie is shown exactly once, on one of the theater's three screens: screens 1, 2, and 3. Screens 1 and 2 show two movies each, one beginning at 7 P.M. and the other at 9 P.M.; screen 3 shows exactly one movie, at 8 P.M. The following conditions apply to this evening's schedule: The western begins at some time before the horror film does. The sci-fi film is not shown on screen 3. The romance is not shown on screen 2. The horror film and the mystery are shown on different screens.
Question: Which one of the following CANNOT be an accurate list of the movies scheduled to be shown on screen 2 this evening, listing the 7 P.M. movie first?
Choices:
  A: the sci-fi film, the horror film
  B: the sci-fi film, the mystery
  C: the sci-fi film, the western
  D: the western, the horror film
  E: the western, the mystery
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  There are three screens in the repertory theater, with two movies playing on Screens 1 and 2 and one movie playing on Screen 3.
  The schedule for the movies has the Western starting before the horror film.
  The sci-fi film is not shown on Screen 3.
  The romance is not shown on Screen 2.
  The horror film and the mystery are on different screens.
Action: Answer("C") 
Explanation: 
  The movie playing on Screen 2 needs to start at 7 PM. 
  The romance is not shown on Screen 2, so it leaves the horror and the mystery movies to be played on Screen 2.
  The sci-fi film is not shown on Screen 3, therefore it should be played on Screen 1 or Screen 2.
  The western should be played before the horror film and C is the only option where the western is played after the sci-fi film on Screen 2. Thus, it CANNOT be an accurate list of the movies scheduled to be shown on screen 2.
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The western begins before the horror film.
  The sci-fi film is not shown in screen 3.
  The romance is not shown in screen 2.
  The horror film and the mystery are shown on different screens.
  Screens 1 and 2 show two movies each, one beginning at 7 P.M. and the other at 9 P.M.
  Screen 3 shows exactly one movie, at 8 P.M.
  
Eliminating options:
  The mystery and the horror film must be shown in screens 1 and 2, though we don't know which is shown on which screen or time.
  Romance is not shown in Screen 2 or time.
  Sci-fi should not be in Screen 3.
  From the western and horror film, the western should play first.

Check for valid options:
  A) The sci-fi movie is in the same list as the horror film which contradicts the given conditions.
  B) Possible
  C) The sci-fi film is played in Screen 2 which contradicts the given conditions.
  D) Possible
  E) The mystery should be played with the horror film which contradicts the given conditions. 

Action: Answer("A") - The option "A" cannot be an accurate list of movies scheduled to be shown on screen 2.

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 85 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A shopping center has exactly seven spaces—space 1 through space 7—arranged in a straight row. Seven businesses—an optometrist, a pharmacy, two restaurants, a shoe store, a toy store, and a veterinarian—will be located in the shopping center, one in each space. The locations of the businesses are subject to the following constraints: The pharmacy must be at one end of the row and one of the restaurants at the other. The two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses. The pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian.
Question: If the shoe store is in space 4, which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: The optometrist is next to a restaurant.
  B: The pharmacy is next to the veterinarian.
  C: A restaurant is next to the toy store.
  D: The shoe store is next to the toy store.
  E: The shoe store is next to the veterinarian.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  We are given a set of constraints on the locations of the businesses in a shopping center.
  The shoe store is located in space 4.
A: There are three possibilities for which business is next to space 1. If a restaurant (either of the two) is located in space 1, then the optometrist must be located in space 2 according to the constraint that the pharmacy be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. However, this would mean the two restaurants are not separated by at least two other businesses, so this configuration is not possible. If the pharmacy is located in space 1, then the optometrist and veterinarian must be located in spaces 2 and 3 in some order. There are two possible configurations with the two restaurants in the remaining spaces (5, 6, and 7), but none of them would place the optometrist next to a restaurant. Finally, if one of the two restaurants is located in space 1, then the other restaurant must be located in space 5 or 6 according to the constraint on separating the restaurants. However, this would not allow space for both the optometrist/veterinarian and the pharmacy, so this configuration is not possible. Therefore, option A is not true. 
B: According to the constraints, the pharmacy must be at one end of the row and must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. If the pharmacy is located in space 1 (because it is one end of the row), then it must be next to the optometrist or the veterinarian. If it is next to the optometrist (in space 2), then the veterinarian must be in space 3. This leaves spaces 5, 6, and 7 for the two restaurants, the toy store, and the optometrist, one of which must be a restaurant. In either configuration with one of the restaurants in space 7, the pharmacy would indeed be next to the veterinarian. Therefore, option B must be true.
C: According to the constraints, the two restaurants must be separated by at least two businesses, but the toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian. This means that neither of the two restaurants can be next to the toy store. Since the shoe store is in space 4, there is room for one restaurant on either side of it. However, neither of those restaurants can be the one next to the toy store. Therefore, option C is not true.
D: We are given that the shoe store is in space 4, but this option claims that it is next to the toy store. According to the constraints, the toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian, and there is no guarantee that the toy store is in space 5 or 3. Therefore, option D is not true.
E: If the pharmacy is located in space 7 (because it is one end of the row), then it must be next to the optometrist (in space 6) or the veterinarian (in space 1). If it is next to the optometrist, then the veterinarian must be in space 5, and the two restaurants must be in spaces 2, 3, and 4 in some order. In this case, the toy store could be in space 7, and the shoe store could be next to the veterinarian. Therefore, option E must be true.
Action: Answer("E")

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 86 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Three rugs will be woven out of colored thread. Six colors of thread are available—forest, olive, peach, turquoise, white, and yellow—exactly five of which will be used to weave the rugs. Each color that is used will be used in only one of the rugs. The rugs are either solid—woven in a single color—or multicolored. The rugs must be woven according to the following rules: In any rug in which white is used, two other colors are also used. In any rug in which olive is used, peach is also used. Forest and turquoise are not used together in a rug. Peach and turquoise are not used together in a rug. Peach and yellow are not used together in a rug.
Question: If there are exactly two solid rugs, then the colors of those two rugs CANNOT be
Choices:
  A: forest and peach
  B: forest and yellow
  C: peach and turquoise
  D: peach and yellow
  E: turquoise and yellow
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  If there are exactly two solid rugs, there must be one multicolored rug.
  If white is used in a rug, two other colors must be used in that rug.
  If olive is used in a rug, peach must also be used in that rug.
  Forest and turquoise cannot be used together in a rug.
  Peach and turquoise cannot be used together in a rug.
  Peach and yellow cannot be used together in a rug.
  
Analysis:
  Let's consider all possible combinations for the two solid rugs:
  - Solid rug 1: forest, Solid rug 2: olive or peach. Multicolored rug: yellow, turquoise, and white.
  - Solid rug 1: olive, Solid rug 2: peach. Multicolored rug: forest, yellow, and turquoise.
  - Solid rug 1: forest, Solid rug 2: turquoise. Multicolored rug: olive, yellow, and white.
  - Solid rug 1: peach, Solid rug 2: turquoise. Multicolored rug: forest, olive, and white.
  - Solid rug 1: forest, Solid rug 2: yellow. Multicolored rug: olive, peach, and turquoise.
  - Solid rug 1: peach, Solid rug 2: yellow. Multicolored rug: forest, olive, and turquoise.
  
  From the above combinations, we see that the colors of the two solid rugs cannot be forest and peach.
  
Action: Answer("A")

  Peach and turquoise cannot be used together in the same rug.
  Peach and yellow cannot be used together in the same rug.

  Since there are three rugs, we know that one of them must be multicolored.
  For a solid rug, only one color is used, so we cannot use any of the restrictions that apply to multiple colors.

  For a rug with white, two other colors must be used, so the third color cannot be used in a solid rug.
  
  Olive requires peach, so if we use olive in one solid rug, we cannot use peach in the other solid rug.
  
  If we use forest in one solid rug, we cannot use turquoise in the other solid rug.

   - In any rug in which white is used, two other colors are also used.

   - Peach and turquoise are not used together in a rug.
   - Peach and yellow are not used together in a rug.

- From the rule, Peach and turquoise are not used together in a rug.
- This option is not valid.

So, options A and B are both valid.

    This combination could be possible as a solid rug.

  D: Peach and Yellow
    This combination could be possible as a solid rug.
  E: Turquoise and Yellow 
    Cannot be a solid combination since only one color would be left, and it would need to be used in the multicolored rug.

Out of the three remaining options, two of them can be used as solid colors. 
Action: Answer("A")
Votes: A, D, D, D, A, A, B, E, B, A
Agent Answer: A
Correct Answer: D

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 87 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Seven workers—Quinn, Ruiz, Smith, Taylor, Verma, Wells, and Xue—are being considered for a special project. Exactly three of the workers will be selected to be project members, and exactly one of these project members will be the project leader. The selection is subject to the following constraints: Quinn or Ruiz can be a project member only if leading the project. If Smith is a project member, Taylor must also be. If Wells is a project member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be.
Question: Verma could be the project leader if which one of the following is true?
Choices:
  A: Neither Quinn nor Smith is selected.
  B: Neither Ruiz nor Taylor is selected.
  C: Neither Smith nor Taylor is selected.
  D: Neither Smith nor Xue is selected.
  E: Neither Taylor nor Wells is selected.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The project leader must be one of the three selected project members.
  Quinn or Ruiz can be a project member only if leading the project.
  If Wells is a project member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be.
  If Smith is a project member, Taylor must also be.
  
  A: Neither Quinn nor Smith is selected --> This means there is no possible project leader, since Quinn can only be a project member if he/she is leading the project, and Smith must be a project member if Taylor is a project member.
  B: Neither Ruiz nor Taylor is selected --> This means either Smith (and therefore Taylor) or Wells is a project member. If Smith (and Taylor) is a project member, then Verma cannot be a project member, so this option is not possible. If Wells is a project member, then neither Ruiz nor Verma can be, which leaves Verma as the only possible project leader. This option is possible.
  C: Neither Smith nor Taylor is selected --> This means that neither Smith nor Taylor can be project members. But if neither Smith nor Taylor is a project member, then Wells cannot be a project member either, since neither Ruiz nor Verma can be project members if Wells is a project member. Thus, there cannot be a project leader under this scenario. This option is not possible.
  D: Neither Smith nor Xue is selected --> This does not provide enough information about who the project members are, so we cannot determine if Verma could be the project leader. This option is not possible.
  E: Neither Taylor nor Wells is selected --> This means either Smith (and therefore Taylor) or Wells is a project member. If Smith and Taylor are project members, then Verma cannot be because if Wells is a project member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be. If Wells is a project member, then neither Ruiz nor Verma can be, which leaves Verma as the only possible project leader. This option is possible.
  
Action: Answer("B")  or Answer("E") since both options are possible.
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  The project must have exactly one leader and three members.
  Quinn or Ruiz can only be a team member if they are the leader.
  If Smith is a member, Taylor must be a member.
  If Wells is a member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be a member.
  
Elimination:
  For Verma to be a project leader, he cannot be a team member. 
  If Verma is not selected, then Wells must be, but if Wells is selected, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be members. Thus Wells cannot be leader.
  
  A: Neither Quinn nor Smith is selected.
    If neither Quinn nor Smith are selected, then Verma could be a member, but without Wells, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be members, so this option is not valid.
  B: Neither Ruiz nor Taylor is selected.
    If neither Ruiz nor Taylor are selected, then Verma could be a member and Quinn could be the leader, so this option is invalid since Taylor must be selected if Smith is a member.
  C: Neither Smith nor Taylor is selected.
    If neither Smith nor Taylor are selected, then Verma could be a member and Quinn could be the leader, so this option is valid.
  D: Neither Smith nor Xue is selected.
    If neither Smith nor Xue are selected, then only Taylor and Verma could be members, but without Wells, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be members, so this option is not valid.
  E: Neither Taylor nor Wells is selected.
    If neither Taylor nor Wells are selected, then Verma could be a member and Quinn could be the leader, so this option is valid.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 2:
Knowledge:
  Exactly three of the seven workers will be selected to be project members.
  Exactly one of the three project members will be the project leader.
  Quinn or Ruiz can be a project member only if leading the project.
  If Smith is a project member, Taylor must also be.
  If Wells is a project member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be.
  
  Analysis:
  For Verma to be the project leader, Verma must be selected as a project member and one of Quinn or Ruiz must also be selected as a project member. Otherwise, Verma will not be eligible for the project leader role. 
  
  A: Neither Quinn nor Smith is selected. - If only one of Quinn and Ruiz can be selected and none of Smith and Taylor can be unselected, then the remaining slot is not enough for Verma to be selected. So, Verma cannot be the project leader. Incorrect.
  B: Neither Ruiz nor Taylor is selected. - If none of Quinn and Ruiz are selected, then Verma cannot be selected as a project member, so Verma cannot be the project leader. Incorrect.
  C: Neither Smith nor Taylor is selected. - In this case, either both Quinn and Ruiz or Wells can be the project members and one can be project lead. So, Verma can be the project leader. But, we cannot be sure of project members without further information. So, this option is possible. 
  D: Neither Smith nor Xue is selected. - We cannot be sure of project members without further information. Incorrect.
  E: Neither Taylor nor Wells is selected. - If Smith is one of the three members selected and the leader, then Taylor must be included. Then, the remaining slot is too small for Verma to be selected. So, Verma cannot be the project leader. Incorrect.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 3:
Knowledge: 
  - Three workers will be selected to be project members, and one will be the project leader.
  - Quinn or Ruiz can be a project member only if leading the project.
  - If Smith is a project member, Taylor must also be.
  - If Wells is a project member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be.
  
Analysis: 
If Verma is the project leader, then he must be a project member too. From the given information, we know that if Wells is a project member, then neither Ruiz nor Verma can be a project member. Therefore, if Verma is the project leader, Wells cannot be a project member.
If neither Taylor nor Wells is selected, then Smith cannot be a project member, hence Smith cannot be the project leader. Ruiz cannot be a project member since Ruiz can be a project member only if leading the project, and since we already know that Smith cannot be the project leader, hence, Ruiz cannot be the project leader either.
If neither Smith nor Xue is selected, then it is possible for Taylor to be selected, and in this case, Verma cannot be a project member, hence Verma cannot be the project leader.
If neither Ruiz nor Taylor is selected, then Quinn must be the project leader, but since Verma cannot be a project member if Wells is a project member, hence Verma cannot be the project leader in this case.
If neither Quinn nor Smith is selected, then it is possible for Taylor to be selected, and in this case, Verma can be a project member and a project leader.

Action: Answer("A")
Response 4:

- Exactly three of the workers will be selected to be project members.
- Exactly one of these project members will be the project leader.

- If Smith is a project member, then Taylor must also be.
- If Wells is a project member, then neither Ruiz nor Verma can be.

We need to determine if Verma could be the project leader based on the given constraints.

If Verma is the project leader, then two project members must be selected from Quinn, Ruiz, Smith, Taylor, Wells, and Xue who satisfy the constraints. We can eliminate options E and D because any of the selected group in these options won't allow Wells to be a project member as required by the constraints. Option A does not allow Quinn to be a project member so we can eliminate it too.

Option B satisfies the constraints as Quinn can be a project member since he can only be if he's leading the project, and Taylor or Wells can join as members. Smith cannot be a member as Taylor can only be a member if Smith is selected.

Option C also satisfies the constraints. Wells can lead the project, Verma and Xue can be project members, and Smith and Taylor cannot be members.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 6:
Knowledge:
  Only three workers will be selected to be project members and only one of them will be the project leader.
  Quinn or Ruiz can be a project member only if leading the project.
  If Smith is a project member, Taylor must also be.
  If Wells is a project member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be.
  
Analysis:
  If Verma is selected to be the project leader, we should evaluate the options which allow her to be selected.
  Only three people will be selected from seven, so we should check the cases where at most two of the people mentioned in the constraints will be selected.
  (A) Neither Quinn nor Smith is selected:
      If Smith is not selected, then Taylor cannot be selected. Since Ruiz can only be a project member if he/she is the project leader, Ruiz cannot be selected too. Finally, Wells should not be selected because if he/she is selected, we cannot select Verma since neither Ruiz nor Verma can be a project member if Wells is selected. Therefore, Verma cannot be the project leader in this case.
  (B) Neither Ruiz nor Taylor is selected:
      If Taylor is not selected, Smith cannot be a project member. Then, Quinn and Wells should not be selected because Ruiz cannot be a project member without being the leader, and Verma cannot be a project member if Wells is a project member. Therefore, Verma cannot be the project leader in this case.
  (C) Neither Smith nor Taylor is selected:
      In this case, Wells can be a project member, which means that neither Ruiz nor Verma can be project members. It also means that if Quinn is selected, he/she should be the leader. So, Verma can be the leader in this case if Quinn is also a project member.
  (D) Neither Smith nor Xue is selected:
      If Smith is not selected, Taylor cannot be a project member, which means Quinn and Ruiz cannot also be project members. If Xue is not selected, Wells cannot be a project member because if Wells is a project member, we cannot select Verma or Ruiz. This means that Verma cannot be a project member too. Therefore, Verma cannot be the leader in this case since she cannot be a project member.
  (E) Neither Taylor nor Wells is selected:
      If Taylor is not selected, Smith cannot be a project member. Then, we should select two project members from Quinn, Ruiz, Xue, and Verma, keeping in mind the limitations mentioned in the constraints. Since only one of them can be the project leader between Quinn and Ruiz and Wells and Verma cannot work together, we should select only one from this group. Therefore, Verma can be the project leader and member in this case.

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 88 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A realtor will show a prospective buyer seven houses—J, K, L, M, N, 0, and P—during a single day. The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning; the third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon; the sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening. The houses will be shown according to the following rules: J must be shown in the evening. K cannot be shown in the morning. L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
Question: Which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: K is shown in the evening.
  B: L is shown in the afternoon.
  C: L is shown in the evening.
  D: M is shown in the morning.
  E: M is shown in the afternoon.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  1. J must be shown in the evening.
  2. K cannot be shown in the morning.
  3. L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
  4. The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning;
  5. The third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon;
  6. The sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening.
  
- From 1, we know that J is shown in the evening.
- From 2, we know that K is shown in the afternoon or in the evening.
- From 3, we know that K and M sandwich L.
- From 4, we know that the first and second houses are shown in the morning, so neither J nor L could be one of the first two houses.
- From 5, we know that L cannot be shown as the fifth, so L must either be shown as the third or as the fourth.
- From 6, we know that J is shown in the last two houses; since L is shown only after K, L must be the last house shown in the afternoon and K must be the first house shown in the evening; also, M must be shown in the evening.

Analysis:
Therefore, we can conclude the following:
- K is shown in the evening, because J is shown in the last two houses.
- L and M are shown in the afternoon and in the evening, respectively.
- Thus, none of the choices A, B, D, or E could be true.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The realtor will show 7 houses to the buyer in a day, two in the morning, three in the afternoon, and two in the evening.   
  J must be shown in the evening.
  K cannot be shown in the morning.
  L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
  
Analysis:
  We know that J must be shown in the evening. Therefore, J cannot be shown in the morning or in the afternoon. It also says that K cannot be shown in the morning, which means that K will either be shown in the afternoon or evening. Since L must be shown after K and before M, and we know that J will be shown in the evening, this leaves only the afternoon for K and L to be shown. It also tells us that M will be shown after L. Therefore, we can conclude that M will be shown in the evening, which means it cannot be shown in the morning or afternoon.
   
Action: Answer("C")
Response 2:
Knowledge:
  The first and second houses are shown in the morning.
  The third, fourth, and fifth houses are shown in the afternoon.
  The sixth and seventh houses are shown in the evening.
  J must be shown in the evening, which means it can only be house 6 or 7.
  K cannot be shown in the morning. That leaves it to be shown in the afternoon or evening.
  L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
  
  (Option A) K cannot be shown in the morning, and it is not required to be shown in the evening.
  (Option B) L must be shown at some time after K is shown, which means K has to be shown before L. Since K cannot be shown in the morning, it needs to be shown in the afternoon with L later in the afternoon, making it house 4 or 5.
  (Option C) L must be shown at some time before M is shown and after K is shown. Since L is shown in the afternoon, M needs to be shown in the evening.
  (Option D) M cannot be shown in the morning, since it is part of the afternoon set of houses along with L and one other house.
  (Option E) M is shown in the afternoon along with L and one other house.

Knowledge: 
  The realtor will show 7 houses in a single day. 
  First and second houses will be shown in the morning. 
  Third, fourth, and fifth houses will be shown in the afternoon. 
  Sixth and seventh houses will be shown in the evening.
  J must be shown in the evening.
  K cannot be shown in the morning.
  L must be shown at a time after K and before M.

Analysis:
  Since J must be shown in the evening, only two houses are left to show at night (i.e., M and N). So, the morning houses must be K and P, whereas the afternoon houses must be L, M, and N. It is known that K is not shown in the morning. Thus, K must be shown in the afternoon. Moreover, since L must be shown after K and before M, the correct order of showing the houses must be P, K, L, N, M, O, and J. Thus, neither K nor L are shown in the evening.

  The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning; the third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon; the sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening.

  Since K cannot be shown in the morning, then K must be shown in the afternoon or in the evening.
  Since L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown, then the possible arrangements for K, L, and M are: KL...M, KLM, or LMK.
  Since the third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon, then L cannot be shown in the afternoon if K is also shown in the afternoon. Also, M cannot be shown in the morning.

Solutions:
A: K is shown in the evening. (Cannot be true because it can be shown in the afternoon)
B: L is shown in the afternoon. (Cannot be true because if L is shown after K and before M, then L cannot be shown in the afternoon)
C: L is shown in the evening. (Can be true if the arrangement is KLM, then L must be shown in the evening after K is shown in the afternoon)
D: M is shown in the morning. (Cannot be true because M cannot be shown in the morning)
E: M is shown in the afternoon. (Can be true if the arrangement is KLM, then M must be shown in the afternoon after L is shown in the afternoon)

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 89 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A government needs to assign new ambassadors to Venezuela, Yemen, and Zambia. The candidates for these ambassadorships are Jaramillo, Kayne, Landon, Novetzke, and Ong. One ambassador will be assigned to each country, and no ambassador will be assigned to more than one country. The assignment of the ambassadors must meet the following constraints: Either Kayne or Novetzke, but not both, is assigned to one of the ambassadorships. If Jaramillo is assigned to one of the ambassadorships, then so is Kayne. If Ong is assigned as ambassador to Venezuela, Kayne is not assigned as ambassador to Yemen. If Landon is assigned to an ambassadorship, it is to Zambia.
Question: If Kayne is assigned as ambassador to Yemen, which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Jaramillo is assigned as ambassador to Venezuela.
  B: Landon is assigned as ambassador to Zambia.
  C: Ong is assigned as ambassador to Zambia.
  D: Jaramillo is not assigned to an ambassadorship.
  E: Ong is not assigned to an ambassadorship.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  If Kayne is assigned as ambassador to Yemen, Jaramillo must also be assigned an ambassadorship since this is a requirement that if Jaramillo is assigned as ambassador to one of the countries, then so is Kayne.

Hence, Jaramillo cannot be assigned an ambassadorship.

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 90 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A concert is given by a six-member band—guitarist, keyboard player, percussionist, saxophonist, trumpeter, violinist. During the concert, each member performs exactly one solo. The following restrictions apply: The guitarist does not perform the fourth solo. The percussionist performs a solo at some time before the keyboard player does. The keyboard player performs a solo at some time after the violinist does and at some time before the guitarist does. The saxophonist performs a solo at some time after either the percussionist does or the trumpeter does, but not both.
Question: Which one of the following CANNOT perform the third
Choices:
  A: guitarist
  B: keyboard player
  C: saxophonist
  D: trumpeter
  E: violinist
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  There are six members in the band: guitarist, keyboard player, percussionist, saxophonist, trumpeter, violinist.
  Each member performs exactly one solo.
  Guitarist does not perform the fourth solo.
  Percussionist performs before keyboard player.
  Keyboard player performs after violinist and before guitarist.
  Saxophonist performs after either percussionist or trumpeter, but not both.

Option Analysis:
  E: Violinist performs before keyboard player, but after that he could perform the third solo.
  D: Trumpeter could perform the first, second, or fifth solo if saxophonist performs after percussionist. And after that, keyboard player could perform the third solo.
  C: Saxophonist performs after either percussionist or trumpeter, but not both. He could perform the third solo if he performs after percussionist, and then keyboard player performs the solo, or if he performs after trumpeter, then guitarist performs solo and keyboard player performs after the violinist.
  A: Guitarist cannot perform the fourth solo. But he could perform the second or fifth solo, and after that, keyboard player performs at third.
  B: Keyboard player performs after violinist and before guitarist. He could perform the third solo.
  
Answer: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The saxophonist performs a solo at some time after either the percussionist does or the trumpeter does, but not both.
  The guitarist does not perform the fourth solo, thus he performs either the first, second, third, fifth, or sixth solo.
  The percussionist performs a solo at some time before the keyboard player does.
  The keyboard player performs a solo at some time after the violinist does and at some time before the guitarist does.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 2:
Knowledge:
  Six band members—guitarist, keyboard player, percussionist, saxophonist, trumpeter, violinist—each performs exactly one solo.
  The guitarist does not perform the fourth solo.

  The keyboard player performs a solo at some time after the violinist does and at some time before the guitarist does.
  The saxophonist performs a solo at some time after either the percussionist does or the trumpeter does, but not both.

Process of Elimination:
  A cannot perform the third solo since the guitarist cannot perform the fourth one.
  B can perform the third solo since she/he can perform a solo after the violinist does and before the guitarist does, both of which are undefined times.
  C can perform the third solo since he/she can perform a solo after either the percussionist does or the trumpeter does, and neither of them are restricted to soloing at any specific time.
  D can perform the third solo since the percussionist is not restricted to performing a solo during the third solo.
  E cannot perform the third solo since the keyboard player's solo must occur after the violinist's.

Answer: Answer("E")
Response 3:
Knowledge:
  Each member performs exactly one solo during the concert.
  The guitarist does not perform the fourth solo.
  The percussionist performs a solo at some time before the keyboard player does.
  The keyboard player performs a solo at some time after the violinist does and at some time before the guitarist does.
  The saxophonist performs a solo at some time after either the percussionist does or the trumpeter does, but not both.

Explanation:
The third solo can only be performed by the saxophonist or percussionist, since they are the only two members who perform after the violinist does and before the guitarist does. The trumpeter performs some time before the saxophonist does or before the percussionist does, thus cannot perform the third solo. Therefore, the answer is D: trumpeter.

  - The percussionist performs a solo before the keyboard player

  - The saxophonist performs after either the percussionist or the trumpeter, but not both.

Response 5:

  - Each of the six members of the band performs one solo during the concert.
  - The guitarist is NOT the fourth performer.
  - The percussionist performs before the keyboard player.
  - The keyboard player performs after the violinist and before the guitarist.
  - The saxophonist performs after either the percussionist or the trumpeter, but not both.

  - From the rules provided, we cannot directly identify which member performs the third solo.
  - We know that the guitarist is not the fourth soloist, but we don't know when they perform.
  - We also know that the keyboard player performs after the violinist and before the guitarist.
  - The saxophonist performs after either the percussionist or the trumpeter, but not both.
  - Therefore, there are 3 possible orderings on who performs the third solo: violinist-saxophonist-keyboard player, percussionist-saxophonist-keyboard player, or trumpeter-saxophonist-keyboard player.
  - Let's go through each member and see if they can fit in any of these orderings.
  
Answer: Answer("A") - The guitarist could possibly perform as the third soloist in the order violinist-guitarist-saxophonist-keyboard player. Therefore, guitarist is not excluded from performing third. The other choices, keyboard player, saxophonist, trumpeter, and violinist all can fit into at least one of the possible orderings for the third soloist. None of the other choices can be eliminated.
Response 6:
Knowledge:
  - There are 6 members in the band, they will perform exactly one solo and will perform in a certain order.
  - The guitarist will not perform the fourth solo.
  - The percussionist will perform a solo before the keyboard player.
  - The keyboard player will perform a solo after the violinist and before the guitarist.
  - The saxophonist will perform a solo after either the percussionist or the trumpeter, but not both.
  
To determine who can't perform at the third solo, we have to derive the order of performances looking at the given restrictions.

1. If the guitarist is performing at either the 1st, 2nd, or 3rd solo, the saxophonist will perform after the percussionist (and trumpeter will perform before the saxophonist). But as per given restrictions, the guitarist can't perform at the fourth solo, so the guitarist must perform at either the 5th or 6th solo.
2. The percussionist can perform first after the guitarist and saxophonist can perform second.
3. The saxophonist cannot perform 3rd because in that case, there will be no option left for the keyboard player to perform as the keyboard player should perform after the violinist and before the guitarist.
4. Thus, we can conclude that the keyboard player will perform third. 
5. After the keyboard player, either the percussionist will perform or trumpeter will perform (as saxophonist cannot perform at 3rd).
6. There are two spots left for solos - one for the guitarist (as per the first restriction) and one for either the percussionist or the trumpeter.
 
From the given choices, we have to identify who cannot perform at the third solo. From our derived sequence, we know that the keyboard player will perform at the third position. So, the answer is not B i.e. keyboard player.

Action: Answer("B")

  The percussionist performs before the keyboard player.
  The keyboard player performs after the violinist and before the guitarist.
  The saxophonist performs after either the percussionist or the trumpeter, but not both.

  If the keyboard player performs third, then the violinist performs before him and the guitarist performs after him. This is not possible due to the positions of the keyboard player and the guitarist. Thus, it's not (B).

  If the trumpeter performs third, then the saxophonist may perform after both the percussionist and trumpeter which is again possible and not in violation of any rules. Thus, it could be (D).
  If the violinist performs third, then the percussionist must have already performed before him and the keyboard player must perform after him and before the guitarist. This is not possible. Thus, it's (E).

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 91 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A chorus director is planning to audition exactly six singers: Kammer, Lugo, Trillo, Waite, Yoshida, and Zinn. Kammer's audition and Lugo's audition will be recorded; the other four will not be. The six auditions are to take place one after the other on a single day, in accordance with the following conditions: The fourth audition cannot be recorded. The fifth audition must be recorded. Waite's audition must take place earlier than the two recorded auditions. Kammer's audition must take place earlier than Trillo's audition. Zinn's audition must take place earlier than Yoshida's audition.
Question: Which one of the following could be the sixth audition?
Choices:
  A: Kammer's audition
  B: Lugo's audition
  C: Trillo's audition
  D: Waite's audition
  E: Zinn's audition
Response 0:
Knowledge:
The fourth audition cannot be recorded.
The fifth audition must be recorded.
Waite's audition must take place earlier than the two recorded auditions.
Kammer's audition must take place earlier than Trillo's audition.
Zinn's audition must take place earlier than Yoshida's audition.
There are six singers total auditioning

Analysis:
Since Kammer's audition and Lugo's audition will be recorded, they must be either the first or second to audition. Since the fifth audition must be recorded, we know exactly where the fifth audition lands, leaving only three possible slots for the fourth audition. Since Waite's audition must take place before the two recorded auditions, Waite must be in either the first or second audition. Kammer's audition must take place before Trillo's so one of their auditions must be in the first three slots. Finally, Zinn's audition must take place before Yoshida's audition so one of their auditions must be in the last two slots.

Action: Answer("C") 
Therefore according to these conditions, Trillo's audition could be the sixth audition.
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  There are six auditions that will take place in succession, with two of them being recorded.
  The auditions have specific conditions that must be met.
  The fourth audition cannot be recorded, and the fifth one must be recorded.
  Waite's audition must take place earlier than the two recorded auditions.
  Kammer's audition must take place earlier than Trillo's audition, and Zinn's audition must take place earlier than Yoshida's audition.
  
Analysis:
  Since Kammer's audition is recorded, it must take place either first or second.
  Since the fourth audition cannot be recorded, and work backwards from the last audition, only Kammer's and Lugo's audition can be the first two auditions that are recorded.
  Waite's audition must be earlier than the second recorded audition, so it must be the first one.
  Kammer's audition must be earlier than Trillo's, so Trillo's cannot be the sixth.

Action: Answer("E") 
  Therefore, the sixth audition could be Zinn's audition.

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 92 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: In the Lifestyle, Metro, and Sports sections of tomorrow's newspaper, a total of six different photographs are to appear, exactly two photographs per section. Each of the available photographs was taken by one of three photographers: Fuentes, Gagnon, and Hue. Selection of the photographs is constrained by the following conditions: For each photographer, at least one but no more than three of that photographers photographs must appear. At least one photograph in the Lifestyle section must be by a photographer who has at least one photograph in the Metro section. The number of Hue's photographs in the Lifestyle section must be the same as the number of Fuentes photographs in the Sports section. None of Gagnon's photographs can be in the Sports section.
Question: If one photograph in the Lifestyle section is by Gagnon and one is by Hue, then which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Exactly one photograph in the Metro section is by Fuentes.
  B: Exactly one photograph in the Metro section is by Gagnon.
  C: Both photographs in the Metro section are by Gagnon.
  D: Exactly one photograph in the Sports section is by Hue.
  E: Both photographs in the Sports section are by Hue.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  At least one photograph in the Lifestyle section must be taken by a photographer who has at least one photograph in the Metro section. Therefore one of the Lifestyle photos is taken by the same photographer who took one of the Metro section photos. 
  If one photo in the Lifestyle section is by Gagnon and one is by Hue then there are six possible combinations of authors: FG, FH, HG, HH, GH, GG (where F stands for Fuentes, G for Gagnon and H for Hue). 
  Fuentes's and Hue's photos in the lifestyle and sports sections respectively must be equal in count.
  Gagnon cannot have photos in the Sports section.
  
Action: Answer('A') 

If Gagnon and Hue provided the Lifestyle photos (i.e. HH or HG) then they cannot have any photos in the Metro or Sports section. This means only Fuentes could have taken the two photos in the Metro section. Therefore, there must be exactly one photograph in the Metro section by Fuentes. Therefore, the statement, "Exactly one photograph in the Metro section is by Fuentes" must be true (choice A).
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  - Three photographers: Fuentes, Gagnon, and Hue
  - Six different photographs will appear, exactly two photographs per section: lifestyle, metro, and sports sections.
  - Each photographer’s photos must be between 1 and 3;
  - No Gagnon's photographs can be in the Sports section;
  - At least one photograph in the Lifestyle section must be by a photographer who has at least one photograph in the Metro section;
  - The number of Hue's photos in the Lifestyle section must be the same as the number of Fuentes photos in the Sports section.
  
Action: Answer("B") 

If one photograph in the Lifestyle section is by Gagnon and one is by Hue, then Fuentes must supply the remaining photo in the metro section. As the number of Hue’s photos in the Lifestyle section must be the same as the number of Fuentes photos in the Sports section, and there can be no Gagnon’s photos in the Sport section - therefore, none of Hue's photos can appear in the Sports section, which means Hue can only have photos in the Lifestyle and Metro sections. So, Gagnon and Fuentes must have photographs in the Sports section. Thus, Exactly one photograph in the Metro section is by Gagnon. is the only answer that must be true.
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  - There are three photographers: Fuentes, Gagnon, and Hue.
  - The newspapers have 3 sections: Lifestyle, Metro, and Sports.
  - Each section has exactly two photographs.
  - No more than three of any photographer's photographs may appear in the newspaper.
  - There must be at least one but no more than three photographs of each photographer in the newspaper.
  - There cannot be any Gagnon photograph in the Sports section.
  - The number of Hue's photographs in the Lifestyle section must be equal to the number of Fuentes photographs in the Sports section.
  - At least one photograph in the Lifestyle section must be by a photographer who has at least one photograph in the Metro section.

Action: Answer("B")  

If one photograph in the Lifestyle section is by Gagnon and one is by Hue, then either Fuentes or Gagnon (but not both) must have at least one photograph in the Lifestyle and Metro sections. Since none of Gagnon's photographs can appear in the Sports section, exactly one photograph in the Metro section must be by either Fuentes or Gagnon. Thus, the correct answer is (B) Exactly one photograph in the Metro section is by Gagnon.

Thus, Choice B is the most likely answer.

### Exam: lsat-ar-100 | Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 93 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookie—oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar. Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday) and each batch is made, from start to finish, on a single day. The following conditions apply: No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day. At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday. The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies. The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
Question: If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Exactly three batches of cookies are made on Tuesday.
  B: Exactly three batches of cookies are made on Friday.
  C: At least two batches of cookies are made on Monday.
  D: At least two batches of cookies are made on Thursday.
  E: Fewer batches of cookies are made on Monday than on Tuesday.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  - A bakery makes exactly three types of cookies: oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  - Exactly three batches of each type of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday).
  - Each batch of cookies is made, from start to finish, on a single day.
  - No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  - At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.

Action: Answer("B")  

If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then exactly three batches of cookies are made on Friday. This is because 3 batches of oatmeal and peanut butter cookies are made by Thursday, and since no two batches of the same kind of cookie can be made on the same day, one batch of oatmeal cookies and one batch of peanut butter cookies must be made on Friday. Therefore, exactly three batches of cookies are made on Friday, and the answer is B.
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  - There are exactly three kinds of cookies: oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  - There are exactly three batches of each kind of cookie every week, for a total of nine batches.
  - Each batch is made from start to finish on a single day.
  - No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  - At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
Question: If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then which one of the following must be true?
Solution:
  - If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, and each kind of cookie has three batches, then we know that the following batches must be made on Wednesday: the third oatmeal, the third peanut butter, and the second sugar.
  - Since the first two batches of oatmeal and peanut butter cookies are made on different days, and the only remaining day is Tuesday, we know that both of those batches must be made on Tuesday.
  - This leaves four batches (the third oatmeal, the third peanut butter, and the first and second sugar) to be made on Monday and Thursday.
  - Since at least one batch of cookies is made on Monday, there must be at least 2 batches made on Monday, leaving only 2 batches for Thursday.
  - Therefore, Option D and Option E are incorrect.
  - Option A is incorrect because only one batch of cookies is made on Tuesday.
  - Option B is correct because all the remaining batches of cookies (which totals four) must be made on Friday.
  - So, the answer is Action: Answer("B").
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  - A bakery makes exactly 3 kinds of cookies.
  - They make exactly 3 batches of each kind of cookie every week from Monday to Friday.
  - Each batch is made on a single day from start to finish.
  - No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  - At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  
Analysis:
  - If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then:
    * Monday must have at least one batch of cookies
    * No other batch of cookie can be baked on Monday
    * No batch of cookie can be baked on Wednesday
    * On Thursday, the second batch of sugar cookies should be baked.
    * This would mean that all guaranteed batches of baking will have been completed
    * The baker will now have to make the last two batches of cookies on the remaining days, which are Tuesday and Friday.
    * Therefore, either 3 batches of cookies are made on Tuesday or 3 batches of cookies are made on Friday
    
Action: Answer("A") 
Therefore, the correct answer is A: Exactly three batches of cookies are made on Tuesday.
Response 3:
Knowledge:
  The bakery makes exactly 3 kinds of cookies, and three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week.
  No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  Second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  Second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then there are exactly two batches of cookies made between Tuesday and Thursday.
  
  A: Cannot be true since the bakery only makes three batches of each kind of cookie per week.
  B: Cannot be true since the bakery only makes three batches of each kind of cookie per week.
  C: If only one batch of cookie is made on Monday, then at least 2 batches of the same cookie type have to be made on another day, to complete the total of 9 batches. Therefore, this statement is true.
  D: If only one batch of cookie is made on Monday, then at least 2 batches of the same cookie type have to be made on another day, to complete the total of 9 batches. This is not necessarily Thursday since the second batch of sugar cookies is already made on Thursday, which completes that day's baking. Therefore, this statement could be true but it is not always true.
  E: This statement cannot be determined from the given information.
  
Action: Answer("C")
Response 4:
Knowledge:
  1. A total of 9 batches of cookies are made each week (3 kinds of cookies x 3 batches each).
  2. No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  3. At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  4. The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  5. The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  
Analysis:
  If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then the 3rd batch of oatmeal cookies cannot be made on Wednesday. Therefore, it must be made on either Tuesday, Thursday, or Friday. If it is made on Tuesday or Friday, then all three batches of oatmeal cookies would be made on the same day as one of the batches of another cookie kind, which violates condition 2. Thus, the 3rd batch of oatmeal cookies must be made on Thursday. Additionally, the second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday, which means no oatmeal or peanut butter cookies can be made on Thursday. Therefore, only one batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday, and the remaining batches of oatmeal and peanut butter cookies must be made on Tuesday and Friday in some order. 

Action: Answer("B") 
Therefore, exactly three batches of cookies must be made on Friday.
Response 5:
Knowledge: 
 The bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookies: oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
 Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week.
 No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
 At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
 The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
 The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
 
Action: Answer("B")  
If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then we know that there will be either two or three batches of cookies made on Friday. If only two batches of cookies were made on Friday, it would mean that all six of the remaining batches were made from Monday to Thursday, and that there would be two batches made on one of those days. However, the prompt states that no two batches of the same kind of cookie can be made on the same day, so this is impossible. Therefore, three batches of cookies must be made on Friday.
Response 6:
Knowledge: 
  A bakery makes exactly three kinds of cookie—oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  Exactly three batches of each kind of cookie are made each week (Monday through Friday) and each batch is made, from start to finish, on a single day.
  No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.

If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then there are only two possible schedules for the bakery.

Monday: oatmeal, peanut butter, sugar
Tuesday: oatmeal, sugar, peanut butter
Wednesday: none
Thursday: sugar, oatmeal, peanut butter
Friday: peanut butter, sugar, oatmeal

or

Monday: oatmeal, peanut butter, sugar
Tuesday: sugar, oatmeal, peanut butter
Wednesday: none
Thursday: peanut butter, sugar, oatmeal
Friday: sugar, oatmeal, peanut butter

Either way, the bakery always makes exactly three batches of each kind of cookies throughout the week. Therefore, the answer is NOT "A" and NOT "E".
Option "B" is not necessarily true since the schedule above showed that the bakery can make fewer than three batches of cookies on Friday.
Option "C" is false because we know that only one batch of cookies can be made on Monday because no two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
Option "D" is also false as we know that only one batch of sugar cookies is made on the same day as the other kinds of cookies. 

Action: Answer("None of the Above")
Response 7:

  - No two batches of the same kind of cookie are made on the same day.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  - At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  - Each batch of cookies is made, from start to finish, on a single day.

Action: Answer("B") 

If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then there must be two remaining days where only two batches of cookies can be made, since there are nine total batches spread amongst Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday. Given that the second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday, there can be no more than one batch of sugar cookies made on either Monday or Tuesday. Thus, if exactly two batches of sugar cookies are made by Friday, then all three batches of oatmeal and peanut butter cookies must be made on Tuesday and Friday, respectively, in order to satisfy the remaining conditions. Therefore, exactly three batches of cookies must be made on Friday. Answer B is correct.
Response 8:
Knowledge:
  - There are 3 types of cookies: oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  - Exactly 3 batches of each type of cookie are made each week, one batch per day.
  - No two batches of the same type of cookie are made on the same day.
  - At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  - The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  - The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  
  If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, it means that there are:
  - 2 batches of cookies made on Tuesday
  - 1 batch of cookie made on Friday
  
Analysis:
  - Since the bakery makes exactly 3 types of cookies, they have to make exactly 3 batches each day from Monday to Friday. Thus, exactly 3 batches of cookies will be made on both Monday and Thursday.
  - From the given conditions, the second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies, which means both of these batches are made on either Monday, Tuesday, Thursday or Friday.
  - Since there are no two batches of the same type of cookie made on the same day, the second batch of sugar cookies must then be made on either Tuesday or Friday.
  - If no batch of cookies is made on Wednesday, then one batch of cookie must be made on Friday. Thus, exactly three batches of cookies are made on Friday.
  
Action: Answer("B")
Response 9:
Knowledge:
  There are exactly three kinds of cookies: oatmeal, peanut butter, and sugar.
  Exactly three batches of each kind of cookies are made each week.
  Each batch of cookies is made on a single day.
  No two batches of the same kind of cookies can be made on the same day.
  The second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of peanut butter cookies.
  The second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.
  At least one batch of cookies is made on Monday.
  If Wednesday is not used, we need to figure out the schedules for the remaining days.
  
Analysis:
  First Batch of Oatmeal cookies can be made on either Monday or Tuesday.
  Second Batch of Oatmeal cookies is made on the same day as the first batch of the Peanut butter cookies.
  Let's say the first batch of the oatmeal cookies is made on Monday, the first batch of peanut butter cookies is also made on Monday, and the second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Tuesday.
  In this case, we have no cookies that can be made on Wednesday, but this requires the second batch of sugar cookies to be made on Wednesday, which is not allowed. Hence this option is invalid.
  Therefore, the only possibility is that the first batch of the oatmeal cookies is made on Tuesday, the first batch of peanut butter cookies is also made on Tuesday, and the second batch of oatmeal cookies is made on Monday. In this case, there are no cookies that can be made on Wednesday, and the second batch of sugar cookies is made on Thursday.

Action: Answer("B")

Topic: Law
Context: A teacher will assign each of five students—Juana, Kelly, Lateefah, Mei, and Olga—to exactly one of two research teams, the green team and the red team. One team will have two members, and the other will have three members. One member of each team will be designated as facilitator. The assignment must satisfy the following conditions: Juana is assigned to a different team than Olga is. Lateefah is assigned to the green team. Kelly is not a facilitator. Olga is a facilitator.
Question: Which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Juana is assigned to the red team.
  B: Lateefah is a facilitator.
  C: Olga is assigned to the green team.
  D: Juana and Mei are not both facilitators.
  E: Neither Juana nor Kelly is a facilitator.
Response 0:

  Juana is on a different team than Olga.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  - There are 5 students: Juana, Kelly, Lateefah, Mei, and Olga.
  - There are 2 research teams: green and red.
  - One team has 2 members, and the other has 3 members.

  - Lateefah is assigned to the green team.
  - Kelly is not a facilitator.
  - Olga is a facilitator.
  - Juana is assigned to a different team than Olga.
  
Using the given conditions:
  - Since Olga is a facilitator and Juana is assigned to a different team than Olga, Juana cannot be a facilitator.
  - Lateefah is assigned to the green team and since there can only be 1 facilitator for each team and Kelly is not a facilitator, Lateefah cannot be a facilitator.
  - Therefore, the green team facilitator must be Olga, and the red team facilitator is Kelly.
  - Also, since Juana is not a facilitator and Olga is, they cannot be on the same team. Therefore, Juana must be assigned to the red team.

Topic: Law
Context: A realtor will show a prospective buyer seven houses—J, K, L, M, N, 0, and P—during a single day. The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning; the third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon; the sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening. The houses will be shown according to the following rules: J must be shown in the evening. K cannot be shown in the morning. L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
Question: Which one of the following could be true?
Choices:
  A: K is shown at some time after J is shown.
  B: L is shown at some time after J is shown.
  C: P is shown at some time after J is shown.
  D: Both N and O are shown at some time after M is
  E: Both N and P are shown at some time after K is
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  There are seven houses - J, K, L, M, N, 0, and P.
  The first and second houses are shown in the morning.
  The third, fourth, and fifth houses are shown in the afternoon.
  The sixth and seventh houses are shown in the evening.
  The rules given are:
    1. J must be shown in the evening.
    2. K cannot be shown in the morning.
    3. L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
  A: K cannot be shown in the morning, and J must be shown in the evening, so K is shown between J and the afternoon showing, making this statement false.
  B: J has to be shown in the evening and L is shown after K, so L has to be shown after J in the evening. This statement is false.
  C: J must be shown in the evening, and P can be shown in the afternoon, thus this is the only statement that could be true. 
  D: This statement is impossible because there are only five houses to be shown in the
    afternoon.
  E: It's impossible for both N and P to be shown in the afternoon because a maximum of three houses are shown at that time, so this statement is impossible.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:

  - J must be shown in the evening.
  - K cannot be shown in the morning.
  - L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
  - The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning.
  - The third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon.
  - The sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening.
  
Analysis:
  - J is shown in the evening, so K cannot be shown after J.
  - L must be shown before M, and since K cannot be shown in the morning, then L must be shown after K.
  - P can be shown at any time, as long as J is shown in the evening.
